#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=La Palma
#Text=La Palma is an island of the Canary Islands , which are an integral part of Spain .
#Text=It is near Morocco , Cape Verde and the archipelagos of the Azores and Madeira , both Portuguese .
#Text=The nickname of the island is " La Isla Bonita " ( the beautiful island ) .
#Text=Understand
#Text=The island has a small population of just under a hundred thousand .
#Text=It has one major port ( Santa Cruz de la Palma ) , a second small port ( Tazacorte ) and an international airport ( SPC ) .
#Text=The populous municipality is Los Llanos de Aridane .

#Text=Ethnically the population is mostly Hispanic ( actually a mix of Spanish , Berber and Portuguese ) , with a small number of European immigrants and very small number of African and Eastern European immigrants .
#Text=The island exports bananas , rum , gofio and some tobacco , and hosts a major international astronomical observatory .
#Text=By ship
#Text=If you want to travel between the islands a good option might be to take a ship if you are in any particular hurry , specially between close by islands .
#Text=Most ferries are now quite modern and cheap .
#Text=The most important companies are Fred Olsen , Transmediterránea and Armas .
#Text=The ferries operate in the .
#Text=There is a regular ferry connection to Tenerife and freight-only ferries to the other islands , to Cadiz in mainland Spain and the African coast .
#Text=By plane
#Text=Santa Cruz de La Palma Airport ( SPC ) .
#Text=Not to be confused with other similarly named airports around the world .
#Text=If you are afraid of the sea or get sick just by staring at a ship
#Text=a plane is what you need , and that usually means a turboprop ATR-72 by one of the local airlines like Binter or Islas Airways .
#Text=They are perfectly safe and adequately fast as you are likely to spend more time at the airport than in the plane itself .
#Text=There are local direct flights to Tenerife , Gran Canaria and El Hierro .
#Text=There are flights with Iberia and Binter to/from several airports in mainland Spain including Madrid and Barcelona , Paris , Madeira and Milan .
#Text=There are charter flights from Belgium , Germany , The Netherlands and mainland Spain .
#Text=Get around
#Text=A hire car is the best option for discovering the remote wilderness regions .
#Text=Roads are well-maintained and marked for traffic control .
#Text=Only sharp turns and verticals on side roads may challenge some drivers .
#Text=By bus
#Text=Buses provide an excellent and reliable service .
#Text=You can print a copy of the timetable here http://transporteslapalma.com/transportes/index.htm .
#Text=A bus ticket never costs more than € 2 if you do n't need to change bus .
#Text=Do not expect the drivers to know more than a couple of sentences in English or German , though they will try to be helpful .
#Text=By taxi
#Text=Taxis can be expensive , and inside a city they are not worth the money unless you are in a real hurry or ca n't balance yourself after a shopping day .
#Text=It is unlikely that you would be cheated .
#Text=From the airport to Puerto Naos costs roughly € 35 ( May 2006 ) .
#Text=See
#Text=There are a few nice towns , but the main attraction is the countryside .
#Text=Spectacular volcanic landscapes reaching up above the clouds with dense vegetation in the valleys make for some spectacular hiking .

#Text=The highest point on the island , El Roque de los Muchachos ( 2426m -- about 8000 feet ) , is easily accessible by car most of the year and the views from there are spectacular and provide a good introduction to the geography of the island ( note that access is restricted at night as this is the site of a major international astronomical observatory -- always read the signposts -- also note that roads and trails can be closed for a few days in the winter due to snow ) .
#Text=There is a very extensive network of marked walking trails over the whole island which are well signposted and walking maps are available from the tourist office in Santa Cruz .
#Text=Along the northeast coast , you 'll find masses of intricately terraced crops ( especially bananas ) interlaced with small towns and villages .
#Text=In the middle of the island there is Caldera de Taburiente , a huge erosion crater which is one of the biggest in the world .
#Text=Guided hikes to the caldera are available .
#Text=During winter months hiking on the river bed in the caldera can be really dangerous because rain can cause flash floods .
#Text=The capital of the island , Santa Cruz , has lots of well preserved old buildings and cobblestone streets .
#Text=Along Avenida Maritima you can see old Canarian balconies made from the Canary pine .
#Text=Observatorio del Roque de los Muchachos .
#Text=Lighthouse of Fuencaliente .
#Text=National Park de la Caldera de Taburiente .
#Text=Parque Arqueologico de Belmaco .
#Text=Roque de Los Muchachos .
#Text=Charco Azul .
#Text=Eco Finca
#Text=Platano Logico
#Text=( near Puerto Naos ) .
#Text=A mostly organic banana orchard with visitor center .
#Text=La Palma Maritime Museum , Plaza de la Alameda ( Santa Cruz de la Palma
#Text=) , ☏ +34922411787 , ✉ reservas@museonavallapalma.es .
#Text=Parque Cultural La Zarza , San Antonio , Garafia , ☏ +34922695005 .
#Text=Archaeological Museum
#Text=Benahoritas
#Text=, Los Llanos de Aridane .
#Text=Do
#Text=Los Tilos laurel forest .
#Text=If possible get four wheel taxi up to start of walk .

#Text=Then walk around the canal ( what in Madeira would be called a levada ) following the contours of a steep tree-lined barranco walking through 13 tunnels ( stooping to avoid hitting your head ) .
#Text=Tunnel number 12 is wet inside - one guide book described it as like a power-shower .
#Text=Then down through the laurisilva forest ( a tiring but stunning descent of about ) .

#Text=Also do n't miss the lookout - a volcanic dyke about two feet wide with sheer drops on both sides , but protected by handrails with totally stunning 360 degree views - makes Symond 's Yat look a bit pathetic .
#Text=Details of the walk are in Walk ! La Palma and also in the Sunflower book guide though take the times given for the walk with a pinch of salt - this took us about 6 hours .
#Text=But well worth the effort .
#Text=See picture at right .
#Text=Ruta del los Volcanos .
#Text=Part of the GR 131 long distance path - along the length of the Cumbre Vieja , a route with fabulous views all round , and with volcanic craters for most of the length .
#Text=Again , quite a demanding walk on a hot day , and dust kicked up by walking companions gets everywhere , but a stunningly memorable walk .
#Text=GR130 walking route .
#Text=For the fit and enthusiastic .
#Text=It goes right around La Palma mainly on the historic donkey paths .
#Text=It takes a minimum of seven days which would require walking around eight hours of tough walking daily .
#Text=If possible take at least a couple of days extra .
#Text=Can be done on a budget by using pensions where possible .
#Text=The constantly changing scenery is stunning , you will meet some interesting locals on the way and it is an experience to remember .
#Text=The island also organsises the Transvolcania which is a run up the Volcano route - and beyond .
#Text=Check out http://www.senderosdelapalma.com/ for info on all walking routes .
